questions.question: They ………………………. come in the evening. (weak possibility)
questions.description: May indicates possibility might indicates very weak possibility. Can is not used in affirmative clauses to talk about possibility.

questions.question: She ………………….. know his address. (possibility)
questions.description: Might is also possible here but it indicates weak possibility.

questions.question: If you spoke English, you ………………………. get a better job. (ability)
questions.description: In type 2 conditional sentences, we use could, not can, to show ability.

questions.question: You ……………………… be watching too many films.
I …………………….. now. (strong obligation)
questions.description: Modals are followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: The roof ………………………. be repaired one of these days.
questions.description: Either must or ought to is possible here. Ought is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: I ………………………… work really hard in those days.
questions.description: Modals do not normally have past forms.

questions.question: You ……………………….. me you weren’t coming.
questions.description: Should have + past participle can be used to express some past ideas.

questions.question: Where is Janet? She …………………….. be in London, Paris or Berlin – nobody knows.
questions.description: Could can express possibility in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: Kashmir ………………………. be very cold in winter.
questions.description: Can indicates behavior typical of a person or thing.
